awd_titl_txt: Advanced Real-Space Measurements with STM: Application to Molecular Monolayers, Monolayer Defects, and Surface Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professors Bumm and Huang and their students at University of Oklahoma are investigating ways to improve measurements of the arrangement and motion of molecules on surfaces to understand how these details affect the chemical and physical properties of the molecules. The ultimate goal is to understand how the properties of molecules, and therefore the surface on which they reside, depend on how molecules pack together. Understanding this relationship is crucial for design of unique surfaces of better bio compatibility and the coatings for corrosion protection and lubrication. The goal of this work is to develop improved tools for measurement and analysis with high precision. This interdisciplinary team combines the research groups of Bumm (experimental physical chemistry) and Huang (theoretical chemical engineering) which provides a unique training ground for graduate and undergraduate students working on the project. University of Oklahoma is a consortial member of the Louis Stokes-Oklahoma Alliance for Minority Participation (LS-OKAMP) in addition to operating the Multicultural Engineering Program (MEP). Both Professors Bumm and Huang are working on actively recruiting students from underrepresented minority groups to their programs, including Native Americans students.

The scanning tunneling microscope (STM) can image surfaces with sub-nanometer resolution, revealing the arrangement of atoms and molecules on the surface. Despite the remarkable resolution, accurate measurements are complicated by the image distortion inherent in the STM. Recent advances in image post-processing by the Bumm group can remove this distortion to a level where accurate real-space measurements to be achieved. This project builds on that success and develops new advanced image analysis methods to characterize motion of molecules in sequences of images. The project develops and tests these methods on self-assembled monolayers (SAMs)--a 2D crystalline organic film, one molecule thick. SAMs are widely used in many areas of science and technology. Although they are well studied, many fundamental questions remain concerning their structure and properties. The analysis methods being developed can measure the position of each molecule in the image to better than 30 pm. Analysis methods to study point defects introduced into SAMs are to be developed and applied to fundamental characteristics of SAMs difficult to perform in other ways. The Huang group provide expertise in molecular dynamics and DFT modeling which is a critical component to bridge the observed STM images with the underlying molecular structure.

por.por_cntn:
The structure of surfaces at the nanometer scale and the exposed chemical functional groups are important for corrosion, friction and wear, wettability, and biocompatibility. We study the structure of the world at the molecular level using the scanning tunneling microscope (STM) to gain a better understanding of that relationship and how it can be controlled. We began developing methods to extract more structural information from STM images [1]. NSF funding helped us fully develop and expand on the initial work. In this work we use statistical methods to perform measurements of 2D ordered molecular monolayers with <10 pm precision where the molecular spacing is 500 pm.

For these studies we use alkanethiol self-assembled monolayers on gold (SAMs) as a model system. These have been well studied since the 1980s, but surprisingly, their structure is not yet fully understood, particularly the structure of the gold-sulfur interface. The real space analysis of our STM images distinctly shows that the molecules in the SAM adopt a four-molecule basis where the four molecules differ in their gold-sulfur bonding geometry and chain twist [2]. That difference can be observed at the air-SAM surface by STM imaging, manifested by a characteristic offset of each basis molecule from the simple close-packed lattice as well as a different statistical fluctuation of their positions. Comparison of STM time-series images shows that the tip condition has a strong influence on the observed molecular shape and SAM surface corrugation, but that what we observe are not imaging artifacts. Understanding these effects will be the subject of future work.

To better understand the interplay of the gold sulfur interface on the alkyl chain structure and the air-SAM interface we used molecular dynamics simulations (MD) to model the alkyl chain structure. We explored ten proposed Au-S interface models. The alkyl chain structure parameters:  twist, tilt direction, and twist basis, are extremely sensitive to the Au-S interface [3, 4]. Only one of the proposed models reproduced the correct unit-cell symmetry. The goal of that study was not to pick the correct Au-S structure, rather to show how proposed structures can be screened. This is important because studies of the Au-S interface typically use x-ray diffraction, which is not very sensitive to the alkyl chain structure parameters. Our approach offers a way to connect the two.

We also explored the Au-S bonding interaction to gain chemical insight. The starting point for that study is the simple adsorption site with no gold surface reconstruction. The goal of that work is to gain chemical intuition, not to elucidate that SAM Au-S interface. We used density functional theory (DFT) to optimize the geometry of a systematically constrained methanethiol molecule. It is known that the most favored adsorption site is slightly offset from the bridge site (sitting between two surface gold atoms). The bonding is strongly dependent on the azimuthal orientation of the S-methyl bond. The most stable position is with the S atom ? of the way toward the fcc hollow site with the S-methyl bond oriented toward the hcp hollow site. There is an analogous site with the S atom ? of the way toward the hcp hollow site with the S-methyl bond oriented toward the fcc hollow site. The energy difference is only 8.1 meV [5]. We showed that the offset from the bridge site and the strong azimuthal orientation dependence can be explained by simple chemical intuition that S atom prefers SP3 hybridization with tetrahedral Au-S-C bond angles. Work is ongoing to understand the fcc-hcp asymmetry [6].

1) M. P. Yothers, A. E. Browder and L. A. Bumm, "Real-space post-processing correction of thermal drift and piezoelectric actuator nonlinearities in scanning tunneling microscope images," Rev. Sci. Instrum. 88 (1), 013708 (2017). http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.4974271

2) M. P. Yothers, "High-precision measurements of alkanethiol self-assembled monolayer structure with scanning tunneling microscopy," PhD Dissertation, University of Oklahoma, 2020. https://hdl.handle.net/11244/325434

3) S. Bhattacharya, M. P. Yothers, L. Huang and L. A. Bumm, "Interaction of the (2√3 ? 3)rect. Adsorption-Site Basis and Alkyl-Chain Close Packing in Alkanethiol Self-Assembled Monolayers on Au(111): A Molecular Dynamics Study of Alkyl-Chain Conformation," ACS Omega 5 (23), 13802 (2020). http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acsomega.0c01111

4) G. Zhou, C. Liu, L. A. Bumm and L. Huang, "Force Field Parameter Development for the Thiolate/Defective Au(111) Interface," Langmuir 36 (15), 4098 (2020). http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acs.langmuir.0c00530

5) S. Bhattacharya, G. Speyer, D. K. Ferry and L. A. Bumm, "A Comprehensive Study of the Bridge Site and Substrate Relaxation Asymmetry for Methanethiol Adsorption on Au(111) at Low Coverage," ACS Omega 5 (33), 20874 (2020). http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acsomega.0c02328

6) S. Bhattacharya, "New structural insights of alkanethiol self-assembled monolayers on the Au(111): a molecular dynamics and density functional theory study," PhD Dissertation, University of Oklahoma, 2021. https://hdl.handle.net/11244/332399
